_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chlorine is the most commonly used substance for disinfecting drinking water.  The addition of chlorine or chlorine compounds to water is called chlorination.  Chlorination is considered to be the most important process for preventing the spread of waterborne disease in drinking water.  The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power (LADWP) also uses chlorine for drinking water disinfection purposes to protect public health per state and federal water quality standards.  Storing and handling large quantities of chlorine can create hazardous situations.  The LADWP takes safety obligations in storing and using chlorine as seriously as it takes in providing safe drinking water.  The LADWP North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station chlorine handling process is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program and Plan and also to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements.  The facilities subject to the EPA and CalARP regulations are required to prepare and update Risk Management Plans (RMPs).  The RMP is to include policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility and the actions, which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency.  The LADWP prepared and submitted RMPs for the North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station in June 1999, June 2004, June 2009, and June 2014. 



Recently, LADWP made significant changes (in June 2014) at the chlorination station, which included the installation of a chlorine dry media scrubber (main scrubber) in place of an existing chlorine wet scrubber. These changes required a revised process hazard analysis for the chlorination station. RMP regulations require the submission of an updated RMP to the regulatory agencies within six months of the significant process change. This Risk Management Plan is the update of the June 2014 RMP.



The LADWP prepared Program Level 2 RMPs in 1999 and 2004 because North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station is not s

ubject to Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations.  However, in the excess of caution, the LADWP decided to prepare Program Level 3 RMPs in June 2009 and June 2014.  Thus, this November 2014 update of the June 2014 RMP also demonstrates compliance with the Program Level 3 requirements. 



The following information is specifically required in the RMP Update Executive Summary: 

* Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.

* General facility and regulated substances information.

* Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.

* Five-year accident history summary.

* Emergency response program summary.

* Planned changes to improve safety.



The above information for the North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station is provided below.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The LADWP accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates the use of proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable requirements of the State of California and EPA's Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  



The LADWP emergency response policy involves the preparation of emergency response plans for hazardous materials which are tailored to each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA and CalARP Program Emergency Response Program Requirements.  The LADWP has prepared an Emergency Response Plan for the North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency.  The Emergency Response Plan has been coordinated with the local response agency (City of Los Angeles Fire Department).  The North Hollywood Wells C

hlorination Station has an excellent record in preventing accidents from occurring.



General Facility and Regulated Substance Information

The North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station is located at 11805 Vanowen Street, North Hollywood, California. This facility chlorinates well water before being supplied to parts of the San Fernando Valley.  In 2014, when the last RMP was being prepared, the chlorination station consisted of a chlorine storage room, a chlorinator room, an instrument room, and a chlorine dry media mini-scrubber to neutralize any chlorine release from the pressure relief vent installed on the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit. The installation of a dry media chlorine main scrubber (replacement of the existing chlorine wet scrubber) of one-ton capacity was also in progress. This dry media chlorine main scrubber has now been installed and is operational. 



The facility currently stores chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the EPA and CalARP Program rules.  A maximum of six one-ton chlorine containers are stored at the North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station. The facility is designed for four of these chlorine containers to be connected to the chlorination process to feed liquid and gaseous chlorine and two others are stored as spares.  The one-ton container is the largest vessel (container) on line. The maximum quantity of chlorine present at the North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station at any given time exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the EPA and the CalARP regulations.  It also exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the federal and the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (CalOSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standards. However, the facility is normally unoccupied and water treatment operators visit the facility daily and respond to any trouble alarms that may occur.  Thus, the LADWP North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station is not subject to the federal or the California OSHA PS

M regulations.



NHWCS consists of a chlorine storage room with chlorine one-ton containers, chlorinator equipment room with chlorinators and evaporators, and an electrical room. The NHWCS also has a chlorine scrubber room which houses a one-ton capacity dry-media type chlorine scrubber (main scrubber). The chlorine storage room, chlorinator equipment room, and the chlorination electrical room are all at ground level.  The chlorine scrubber room is located below the electrical and equipment rooms with the scrubber discharge passing through the roof of the building near the southeast corner. The manufacturer makes performance claims of a maximum chlorine concentration of 25 ppb on the scrubber discharge under design chlorine loading rates. The station has two separate sources of power, thereby minimizing the potential for a power failure.  The emergency response is coordinated from the LADWP Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP).



As mentioned above, a maximum of six one-ton chlorine containers are stored at the North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station. The facility is designed for four of these chlorine containers to be connected to the chlorination process to feed liquid and gaseous chlorine and two others are stored as spares.  The gaseous chlorine system is the station's primary system, and the liquid chlorine system is the backup system.



In normal operation, two banks of chlorine containers (each bank containing two chlorine containers) are used to supply gaseous chlorine to the process.  All the four containers are equipped with Halogen actuators (emergency shutoff system) on the angle valves and feed gaseous chlorine under pressure. The actuators will close the angle valves when a chlorine concentration of 10 ppm is detected in the room.  The gaseous chlorine withdrawn from the chlorine containers bypass the evaporators. One bank of two chlorine containers serves as the primary bank and the second bank serves as an automatic backup when the pri

mary containers run dry. Space is allocated in the room for the storage of two additional containers that are not provided connections to the system.  The gaseous chlorine then proceeds to vacuum regulator check unit. Chlorine gas under vacuum from the vacuum regulator check unit is fed to one of the four chlorinators that regulate the flow of chlorine.  From there, gas then travels under vacuum to the injectors. It is important to note that in case of loss of vacuum downstream of the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit, air would be drawn in rather than chlorine being released and the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit will shut down the chlorine supply to the chlorinator, operating as a shut-off valve.



The gas header line is equipped with automatic switchover vacuum regulating valves (vacuum regulating valve with check-relief vent), and pressure gauges.  The primary 

(gaseous chlorine) bank provides all the chlorine to the station until it is depleted.  The other gaseous chlorine bank automatically starts supplying chlorine when the primary bank is depleted.  This automatic system is achieved by setting the automatic vacuum regulating valve leading from the secondary bank to standby.  Once the primary bank is depleted, the higher vacuum level acts on the diaphragm of the automatic switchover vacuum regulator in the secondary bank, thereby pulling that valve open to start feeding gas.



There are a total of eight injectors. Six injectors are located inside the station. The injectors draw chlorine gas into mixing water to form a concentrated solution.  The solution is piped to diffuser tubes located in the water distribution pipelines. Residual chlorine analyzers monitor residual chlorine downstream of the diffusers.

 

The chlorine storage and chlorinator rooms have each been equipped with two Milram chlorine leak sensors (two sensors in each room) tied in to the Milram monitor in the chlorination electrical room.  Additional sensors ar

e located in the suction and discharge ducts for the chlorine scrubber, as well as in the West Well Collector Line injector cabinet.  The detector is able to detect and provide warning of the presence of chlorine gas in the air, giving a locally audible and flashing red light alarm when chlorine concentration exceeds 1.0 ppm by volume.  The scrubber room is equipped with a Mil-Ram leak sensor, which turns off the room ventilation system at 1.0 ppm.  The outputs from the sensors (0-20 ppm) are monitored by the SCADA system. The values can be read and alarms are generated by the system computer at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) control room.  The computer generates the alarm and immediately posts it on a computer terminal screen located in the LAAFP control room.  Additionally, an audio alarm is initiated to further alert control room personnel.  Acknowledgement of chlorine alarms is done at this terminal.  Furthermore, the detection of a chlorine concentration of 10 ppm on any two of those four sensors causes the Halogen actuators to close the angle valves on the containers. The detector system has a battery backup.  Thus, the detector system will continue operating even during a power failure.



The North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station had a wet caustic soda based chlorine scrubber system (main scrubber).  This wet chlorine scrubber was recently replaced with a more reliable, efficient, and functionally similar dry-media type chlorine scrubber.  The scrubber is actuated by the chlorine detectors at a chlorine concentration of 3 ppm that can neutralize up to 2,350 lb of chlorine. The manufacturer makes performance claims of a maximum chlorine concentration of 25 ppb on the scrubber discharge under design chlorine loading rates.  The discharge stack is located on the roof of the building.



A dry media chlorine "mini-scrubber" unit (MS) has been installed at the NHWCS. MS is an emergency chlorine scrubber intended to protect personnel workin

g in the building or immediate area from a chlorine gas release from the pressure relief vent installed on the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief units. Mini-scrubber can neutralize up to 25 lbs of chlorine, and the media manufacturer specifies chlorine removal to less than 5 parts per billion. The mini-scrubber is activated automatically at a chlorine concentration of 1 ppm.



In the event power is lost at the chlorination facility, an alarm will alert the LAAFP control room.  Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences. The station is powered by two separate power supplies. 



The facility is normally unoccupied; water treatment operators visit the facility daily. A response team coordinated from LADWP Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) responds to any trouble alarms which may occur. Access to the facility is through gates, which are kept locked all the time.



Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The LADWP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

* Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.

* Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.

* Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.

* Performance of process hazard analysis review of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.

* State-of-the-art process and safety equipment.

* Accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the station operators.

* High level training for the operators and maintenance staff.

* A State of California Water Treatment Facility Staff Certification is required to operate the station.

* An incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.



Chemical-specific prevention steps include the following: availability of self-conta

ined breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply; awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine; presence of chlorine detectors with remote monitoring; use of Halogen actuators on the ton containers; a chlorine dry media main scrubber, and a  chlorine dry media mini-scrubber.



Process and Chemical Safety Information

Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background information and MSDS sheets.



Equipment safety information was compiled on the chlorination process.  Specifications for the chlorination process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference.  Details (such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; and safe upper and lower pressures for the chlorination facility) are on file at the facility.  The LADWP also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.



Process Hazard Analysis 

In 1991, a detailed hazard review/process hazard analysis was conducted for the chlorination system equipment and procedures.  The hazard review was further reviewed in April 1999.  In April 2004 a hazard review was again performed for the whole chlorination system. The 2009 Hazard review/PHA was further reviewed in March 2009.  A PHA was performed on August 17, 2012 for the replacement of the existing chlorine wet scrubber at the North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station with a dry scrubber. A PHA was again performed on March 14, 2014 for the full chlorination system because the chlorine wet scrubber was removed from the chlorination station but the dry scrubber was still under installation. In addition, the LADWP had decided to withdraw only gaseous chlorine from

the ton containers till the dry scrubber was installed at the chlorination station. A list of recommended actions was developed in March 2014 to further improve the chlorine safety. These recommendations have been evaluated by the LADWP staff and have been implemented.



Another PHA for the chlorination station after the installation of the dry media chlorine scrubber was performed on November 14, 2014. Based on this PHA, one recommendation was made to further improve the chlorine safety and the LADWP staff is currently evaluating this recommendation. Staff will document the completion of the recommended action. The November 14, 2014 PHA will be updated again within a five-year period or whenever there will be a major change in the process.



A seismic walkthrough was completed on November 4, 2014 for the dry media chlorine main scrubber system. Based on the November 2014 engineering review of the scrubber system, no additional recommendation was made. The seismic assessment was performed following the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) Region 1 guidance document.



Operating Procedures

The LADWP has prepared written operating procedures for North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities relating to chlorination process. They are consistent with the chlorine safety information.  Written operating procedures included in the facility's Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Manual include:

* Delivery of Chlorine.

* Container Connections.

* Initial Startup Procedure.

* Normal Operation.

* Normal Shutdown.

* Temporary Operations.

* Emergency Operations.

* Emergency Shutdown.

* Startup Following Emergency Shutdown.



Training 

The LADWP ensures that each employee operating or maintaining the chlorination process, and each employee newly assigned to this process, is trained and tested for competency in the operating procedures listed above. The LADWP employee training documentation files

include training records for each employee assigned to operate or maintain the chlorination process. The training ensures that the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely perform the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.  Employee training includes as a minimum the following elements:

* Safety Information.

* Process Technology and Process Equipment, including safety systems.

* Maintenance Procedures.

* Operating Procedures for the chlorine system.

* RMP Program contents.

* Emergency Response Plan and Procedures.



Refresher training is provided at least every three years to each employee operating the chlorination process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, the LADWP ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after major modifications.  



Contractors

The LADWP Contractor's procedures specify the information required to be provided to the contractors performing work on or near the chlorination process, the training requirements for contractor employees, and mechanism to obtain assurance from contractors that they have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules.  The LADWP provides information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes. 



Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

The LADWP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting a new covered process or prior to making modifications to the chlorination systems that require a Management of Change (MOC) procedure implementation.  The required conditions prior to startup include the following:

* Construction and/or equipment are in accordance with design specifications.

* Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.

* A PHA has been performed for

any new facilities and recommendations have been resolved or implemented prior to startup.

* At modified facilities, MOC requirements have been met.

* Training of each operating and maintenance employee involved in the process is complete.



These procedures ensure that no new and/or new/significantly modified process will startup and no regulated substances will be introduced into such a process before the pre-startup safety review.  This constitutes a final check that the process and equipment are ready to go and that the recommendations of the PHA have been implemented or adequately addressed.  This will ensure that the design and construction of a new or modified process is safely executed and that the facility is prepared to operate it. 

Mechanical integrity procedures for the plant ensure that written maintenance procedures are implemented and documented, including training of maintenance personnel.



Maintenance 

The LADWP operates a maintenance program, MAXIMO Program that generates a work order for performing the preventive maintenance routine, which occurs after a designated time past the closing of the previous work order for that particular maintenance process.  Description of the work to be performed is included with the printed work order.  The water treatment supervisors are responsible for the maintenance of the chlorination system.  

In addition, the written maintenance procedure is provided in the O&M Manual as follows: Preventive maintenance schedules are provided which summarize inspection, test, and maintenance schedules on a daily, weekly, bi-monthly, monthly, biannual, and annual, every 2 to 10 years, and as-needed basis.  These procedures allow the operator to rapidly review what maintenance is necessary.  The schedules are supplemental to the log sheets on-site and provide a summary and quick reference to manufacturer's O&M manuals.  A maintenance log book is provided on-site for Operator quick reference.



The LADWP documents inspe

ction, testing, and maintenance of chlorination equipment and assures the performance is performed in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer and industry groups (i.e., Chlorine Institute).



Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 

Hot work refers to work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or similar flame or spark producing operations.  The hot work procedures require the issuance of a hot work permit whenever it is conducted on or near the chlorination process and other areas deemed appropriate as described in these procedures.  Fire prevention and protection systems are in place before a hot work permit is issued. The permit indicates the dates the work is authorized for, the location, and specific operational requirements, and it is kept on file in the administrative office. 



The LADWP Management of Change procedures include steps required to be taken by plant personnel before implementing changes to chlorination equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions.  Training, process safety information, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures are updated according to the changes made.



Internal Compliance Audits

The LADWP has been certifying every three years (or earlier) that compliance with Program 2 Prevention Program requirements is met and that procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed. Starting June 2009, the LADWP certified compliance with Program 3 Prevention Program requirements. The two most recent audit reports and a list of the recommendations are retained in the LADWP's files.



The compliance audit consists of separating the RMP program elements or sections, and auditing each element to determine compliance and effectiveness.  For each internal audit, the audit team completes a Compliance Audit Certification Page and a Compliance Audit Checklist.  The Compliance Audit Certification Page provides process identification, the dates of the audit, team members, a

nd certification by the audit leader.  The Compliance Audit Checklist details the requirements of each RMP element and contains questions that may assist with the auditing process. The audit checklist for each element consists of the following three sections:

* Records Review: A review of the RMP written Prevention Program.

* Onsite Conditions: The audit team reviews the program elements based on observation of the plant conditions and safety practices.

* Interviews:  The program elements are evaluated by interviewing personnel from appropriate functions including operations, maintenance, management, and contractors.

Team members record RMP program deficiencies identified during the audit on the checklist.



Incident Investigation

The LADWP incident investigation procedures describe incident reporting, investigation, and investigation reporting steps to be followed by plant personnel. The incident investigation is started promptly but no later than 48 hours after the event.  The LADWP promptly addresses and resolves all recommendations and implements the recommendations in a timely manner to prevent an incident recurrence.  All incident investigation reports are retained in the LADWP's file for at least a period of five years from the date the reports are completed.



Five-year Accident History Summary

No chlorine releases that could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the North Hollywood Wells Chlorination Station during the last five years.



Emergency Response Program Summary

The LADWP is a first responder, its employees respond to chlorine accidental releases.  In the event an accidental release that could result in offsite consequences occurs, external resources, such as the City of Los Angeles Fire Department will also be solicited to respond.  



As part of the emergency response program, the LADWP has developed and implemented an emergency response

plan for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. The following elements are included:

(a)    An emergency response plan, maintained at the North Hollywood Wells  Chlorination Station  and at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) containing:

* Organizational structure (chain-of-command) and responsibilities of various LADWP personnel.

* Procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations.

* Details of the training programs for all employees involved with the chlorination process, contractor training, and medical surveillance of LADWP personnel who respond to chlorine releases.

* Details of emergency recognition and prevention at the LADWP.

* Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.

* Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures and the detailed information on emergency health care.

* Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release.

(b)    Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance. 

(c)    Training in relevant procedures for all employees involved with the chlorination process.

(d)    Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes and ensure that employees are informed of changes.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

As part of updating the 2009 Risk Management Plan, a PHA was performed in March 2014 for the chlorination system. Based on the March 2014 PHA, a few equipment and procedural changes were recommended. These recommendations have been evaluated and implemented by the LADWP. Additionally, one recommendation was made (based on November 14, 2014 PHA) to further improve chlorine safety. It is expected that this recommended action would be evaluated by May 2015 and implemented by November 2015. The implementation of this recommendatio
n will further improve the safety of the chlorine system.
